entry.title: Re: AR Invoice showing incorrect stock quantity
entry.content:
The reasons could be

since INV1.U_KD_BRNG_PJK is defined as Alphanumeric (length 20), it is stored as a string, not a number. If your query is trying to treat it as a number (e.g., using SUM, CAST, or numeric comparison), it may default to 0 if the string isn't parsed correctly.

The value 281100 may look clean in the UI but contain leading/trailing spaces, non-printable characters (e.g., carriage return, tab), invisible formatting from copy-paste or integration. These can cause SQL functions to misinterpret the value.

If your query includes a WHERE clause or joins that filter out the invoice, it may return 0 because the row is excluded. Double-check that the invoice number is included in the query result set.

Since this issue occurs only in one invoice, compare it with others where the query works. Look for differences in how the UDF was populated ‚Äî manually vs. via integration, copy-paste, etc.

entry.title: Re: Discrepancy in TDS Deduction During CN Booking
entry.content:
TDS is calculated based on Withholding Tax Type, Withholding Tax Code, Vendor Master Data & Invoice Posting Date. If the CN uses a different posting date, tax code, or vendor configuration, SAP may default to the standard rate (2%) instead of the LDC rate.

Check if the LDC validity period covers the CN posting date. If the CN was posted outside the LDC window, SAP will apply the default rate.

Go to FK03 or BP and check withholding tax code assigned to the vendor, whether the LDC rate (1.35%) is correctly maintained and whether the CN posting logic bypasses or overrides this setup.

entry.title: Need Help
entry.content:
The client requires a report of the actual weights provided by the warehouse after the goods have been packed and the entire pallet has been weighed. The macro adjusts the discrepancies between the actual weight and the SAP weight by proportionally adding or subtracting kilograms from the SAP weight for each line item on the given pallet. This adjustment is made proportionally for each reference on the pallet.
For below example, if the actual weight is 10 kg less than the SAP weight, the macro will subtract 8 kg proportionally from reference PN A and 2 kg from PN B.
We are unable to set the actual weight directly in SAP because there are deviations in the weight of individual references. The client does not accept these deviations and wants the actual pallet weight to be reflected accurately. Therefore, we need to adjust the weight per reference so that the totals sum up correctly.
The macro adjusts the weights proportionally across all products on a given pallet based on the difference between the actual measured weight and the SAP weight.
It then recalculates the quantities into pieces (gross/net), assuming a tare weight of 25 kg.
 
For example, if a pallet weighs 510 kg in SAP but actually weighs 500 kg, and contains:
    PN A ‚Äì 410 kg
    PN B ‚Äì 100 kg
After running the macro, the adjusted weights become:
    PN A ‚Äì 402 kg
    PN B ‚Äì 98 kg
How can we implement this so we can see actual weight on invoices????

entry.title: Edge Integration Cell Vs Kafka On-premise
entry.content:
Hello experts,

We have SAP Integration Cell deployed on Azure. Everything is working correctly. Now we want to connect to our on-premise Kafka 2.1 server on Linux.

We've developed a simple test interface in CPI. We are using the Kafka adapter, which asks for an authentication type. Our Kafka server doesn't have any authentication defined; we only filter by IP.

Even with the rules enabled to allow connectivity from the Azure Integration Cell, we are the same error.

The test button from Monitor "Connectivity Test" also gives the same error.

Any suggestions?

java.util.concurrent.ExecutionException: org.apache.kafka.common.errors.TimeoutException: Timed out waiting for a node assignment. Call: listTopics Cause: org.apache.kafka.common.errors.TimeoutException: Timed out waiting for a node assignment. Call: listTopics

Thanks

entry.title: 5 Essential Points for a Successful Closing of the PREPARE Phase in SAP S/4 Cloud Private Projects
entry.content:
When we think about agile and structured methodologies, SAP Activate stands out as the framework that guides each stage of an SAP implementation. And within this cycle, the PREPARE phase plays a fundamental role: it is the moment to ensure the foundation is solid before moving forward to Explore.

A well-executed closure of the PREPARE phase can mean the difference between an agile, sustainable, well-governed project ‚Äî or one full of risks that will appear soon after.

The SAP Activate Methodology Roadmap provides comprehensive information to support this stage. However, if you need a quick reference guide, below are the 5 key points that should be considered at this moment. For additional references, I‚Äôve included at the end of this post the link to the full Roadmap.

1. Confirmation of the Governance Structure

The PREPARE phase must close with a clear and functional governance in place:

  • Steering Committee, PMO, and other bodies defined

  • Roles and responsibilities distributed between customer, integrator, and SAP

  • Clear escalation paths for risks, issues, and change requests

 

2. Full Team Mobilization

It is essential to confirm that all key teams are mobilized:

  • Customer and partner project teams

  • Identification of Key Users and Subject Matter Experts (SMEs)

  • Commitment and availability validated for each role

 

3. Technical Landscapes Available

At the closure of PREPARE, the technical environment must be ready:

  • DEV, QAS systems and initial connections configured

  • Access granted to all users involved in Fit-to-Standard workshops

  • Initial priority integrations mapped

4. Detailed Explore Phase Plan

Closing PREPARE means starting Explore with a clear agenda of workshops, deliverables, and acceptance criteria:

  • Full schedule of Fit-to-Standard workshops

  • Methods and tools for capturing requirements (e.g., SAP Signavio, Solution Manager, templates)

  • Change management and communication plan defined

 

 

5. Risks and Dependencies Formally Registered

Finally, all risks identified so far must be formally documented and mitigated:

  • External dependencies (customer infrastructure, master data, third-party contracts)

  • Training and knowledge curve challenges for the project team

  • Budget and availability constraints

 

Conclusion

Properly closing the PREPARE phase is more than a formal milestone ‚Äî it ensures the project moves forward with agility, predictability, and a focus on success.

With structured governance, mobilized teams, available systems, a detailed plan, and documented risks, the journey into Explore becomes much more solid and reliable.

The result? A project ready to evolve with technology and deliver the business value expected from SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link to the SAP Activate Roadmap related to this phase:
https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec...

entry.content:

- migration cockpit items (master records, dependent master records, transactional records) dependency and sequence
- migration cockpit items relationship to best practices scope items (example, scope item J45)

I recall other SAP methodologies (like the cloud launch) that offered this accelerator (see attached the screenshot DM Plan Sample).

entry.title: 5 pontos essenciais para um bom fechamento da fase PREPARE em projetos SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private
entry.content:
Quando pensamos em metodologias √°geis e estruturadas, o SAP Activate se destaca como o guia que orienta cada etapa de um projeto de implementa√ß√£o SAP. E dentro desse ciclo, a fase PREPARE tem um papel fundamental: √© o momento em que garantimos que toda a funda√ß√£o esteja s√≥lida antes de avan√ßar para o Explore.

Um fechamento bem-feito da fase PREPARE pode significar a diferen√ßa entre um projeto √°gil, sustent√°vel e bem-governado ‚Äî ou um projeto cheio de riscos que surgir√£o logo adiante.

O Roadmap da metodologia SAP Activate apresenta informa√ß√µes bem completas para apoio nesse momento. Mas caso precise de um guia para refer√™ncia r√°pida, deixo abaixo os 5 pontos chave que devem ser considerados neste momento. Como mais refer√™ncias, deixo ao final deste post o link para o Roadmap completo.

1. Confirma√ß√£o da Estrutura de Governan√ßa

A fase PREPARE deve encerrar com uma governan√ßa clara e funcional:

  • Comit√™s definidos (Steering Committee, PMO, etc.)

  • Responsabilidades bem distribu√≠das entre cliente, integrador e SAP

  • Regras claras para escalonamento de riscos, problemas e mudan√ßas

2. Mobiliza√ß√£o Completa da Equipe

√â essencial confirmar que todas as equipes-chave est√£o mobilizadas:

  • Time de projeto do cliente e do parceiro

  • Defini√ß√£o dos Key Users e SME‚Äôs

  • Confirma√ß√£o de disponibilidade e pap√©is atribu√≠dos

3. Ambientes T√©cnicos Dispon√≠veis

No encerramento do PREPARE, deve-se assegurar que a paisagem t√©cnica m√≠nima esteja pronta:

  • Ambientes DEV, QAS e acessos configurados

  • Usu√°rios habilitados para os Fit-to-Standard

  • Integra√ß√µes priorit√°rias mapeadas

4. Plano Detalhado de Atividades do Explore

Fechar o PREPARE significa entrar no Explore j√° com uma agenda clara:

  • Cronograma dos workshops Fit-to-Standard

  • M√©todos e ferramentas de captura de requisitos (ex.: Signavio, Solution Manager)

  • Plano de comunica√ß√£o e gest√£o de mudan√ßas

5. Riscos e Depend√™ncias Formalmente Registrados

Por fim, todos os riscos identificados at√© aqui devem estar registrados, categorizados e com planos de mitiga√ß√£o:

  • Depend√™ncias externas (infraestrutura, dados, contratos)

  • Desafios de capacita√ß√£o da equipe

  • Restri√ß√µes de or√ßamento e disponibilidade

Conclus√£o

Encerrar bem a fase PREPARE n√£o √© apenas um marco formal ‚Äî √© a garantia de que o projeto seguir√° com agilidade, previsibilidade e foco no sucesso.

Com governan√ßa estruturada, equipe mobilizada, ambientes prontos, plano detalhado e riscos mapeados, a jornada rumo ao Explore se torna muito mais s√≥lida e segura.

O resultado? Um projeto pronto para evoluir junto com a tecnologia e para entregar o valor de neg√≥cio esperado com o SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition.

Link para o Roadmap SAP Activate relacionado a esta etapa:
https://me.sap.com/roadmapviewer/group/658F507A-D6F5-4B78-9EE1-0300C5F1E40F/roadmapcontentpage/a11ec...

entry.title: Re: Open Orders Report to Customers
entry.content:
Hello @AdamHorne 

There is no direct function to automatically email CDS results like an open order report to external customers on a recurring basis ins public cloud. However, there are some supported approaches that you can consider using.

I recommend you consult the following links for more information.

Custom CDS Views,  SAP Build Process Automation  &  SAP S/4HANA Cloud  Output Management

To summarise the options, you can consider scheduling your custom CDS query or analytical story using the:

  • embedded analytics and Email notification through the output management.
  • Use output parameter determination to trigger a custom form that is linked to your custom CDS query. This works if you want to generate a PDF document and send it via output management.
  • Use SAP Build Process Automation or Integration Suite. You can explore the BTP to automate it. This solution is very commonly used best practice in public cloud projects.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: I got an error when try to access my site
entry.content:
Hello @joredudiaz 

Have a look at the following links for guidance.

Integrating With SAP Build Work Zone, Standard Edition

Configuring Destinations for Exposing Content and Consuming Content

Configure SAP Build Work Zone

Setting Up Trust Between Identity Authentication and SAP BTP

Here is a quick summary. Based on your screenshot and the error message, the issue is not with the tutorial steps themselves but with the authentication or destination setup between SAP Work Zone and your S4 cloud system. This typically happens when there is a misconfiguration in your destination or there is a missing setup in IAS. Consider rechecking your destination URL, authentication and role assignments.

Here are a few areas to cross check.

  • Ensure your destination in your BTP subaccount is pointing to the correct API endpoint of your S4 tenant.
  • Ensure your BTP subaccount is correctly trusted with the cloud Identity services.
  • Ensure your test user account has the role collections required for the apps you want to embed in work zone.
  • Check if the communication scenario you created for S4 √† work zone integration includes the correct redirect URL.
  • In your test destination, check connection for destination. If this fails adjust it until you get a green check.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: quotation error : Unpermitted combination of business...
entry.content:
Hi @mohammed_annabi 

Thank you for your question.

The error message you are getting appears because the standard Sales Order migration object in the S4 migration cockpit does not support sales document category B. This happens because the migration cockpit provides predefined migration objects for specific business processes. BUS2023 is limited to sales orders. Quotations are not supported as a loadable object. The LTMOM is adjustable in Private Cloud or on-premise. However, this is not possible in public cloud.

Have a look at the following links for more details. Migrate Your Data - Migration Cockpit

Interface SalesQuotationService

I recommend you:

  • Check in your migration cockpit and verify the list of standard objects, you will see that quotations are not included.
  • Alternative options would be to manually create quotations or use API-Based upload.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to Link Custom CDS Data to a Standalone Form in S...
entry.content:
Hello @CarmenRuiz 

Thank you for your question.

Based on your scenario description, you want to print labels via a form linked to FDP_PP_MOR_DATA_LIST_SRV but you need to enrich it with custom Z fields from your MES CDS view.

Have a look at the following links Extending the Form Template with Custom Fields, Custom Business Objects, Fields, and Logic & BAdIs for Output Data Modification

  • Answer to question 1: No, only FDP released services can be linked. This means you must enrich them.
  • Answer to question 2: Yes, if your Z fields are business context oriented. You can create them as a custom field and then expose them through the data source extensions.
  • Answer to question 3: If your fields come only from MES CDS and cannot be created as CFL custom fields, then you have to implement the BAdI to enrich the form payload.

Those steps also ensure you adhere to the best practice.

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Extensibility Custom Field - Professional services -...
entry.content:
Hello @Amgad-El-Stohi 

Thank you for your question.

Based on your description, there seem to be an extensibility gap with professional services to Project Billing in the public cloud. Your set up is correct, the issue seems to be that PDR to BDR handover logic does not automatically include your new custom field even though you see it in both UIs.

Consider the following links for details. Flexible Aggregation of Billing Output for Professional Services,

Managing Billing for Services, & BAdI for Billing Documents.

The blog you referenced also explains why coding block extensibility alone does not cover transfer logic.

I recommend you:

  • Check the business scenario enablement, the crucial piece here is the coding block to billing document item for project billing. Make sure this scenario is published after enabling. If not the field does not flow downstream.
  • Consider implementing a BAdI to read your custom field value from the PDR item and assign it to the BDR structure

I hope this provides the desired insight. Happy to answer any further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Wily Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 Installation
entry.content:
Customer would like to know how to install and deploy Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Wily Introscope Enterprise Manager 10.8 Installation
entry.content:
Dear customer,

Introscope EM 10.8 SP01 could be installed with reference of below Note/KBA:

Download Media:

Download WILYISEM01*.zip and WILYISMM01*.zip as per Note 3247270

 

Install EM SP01 and Management Module SP01 refer to KBA3578130(Windows):

Installation procedure for EM SP01:

  1. Download WILYISEM01*.zip for EM SP01.
  2. Create Installation directory of your choice (In previous versions, by default Introscope used to create and install in this directory: /usr/sap/ccms/apmintroscope). Now extract the Zip file in the installation directory. Then extract the em-sap-noinstaller-dist-*.zip in the same installation directory.
  3. Open file ca-eula*.txt in a text editor, read the license, and modify the last line to read CA-EULA=accept. If the license is not accepted installation will fail.
  4. At this point there are multiple jre directories created (example: jre-windows, jre-linux) in the installation directory. Open the command prompt from the installation directory and as per your operating select the specific jre and execute like below examples
    For windows : ‚Äòjre-windows-x64\bin\java -jar product-configurator.jar -e ca-eula.silent.txt -r installer.properties‚Äô
    For linux : ‚Äòjre-linux-x64/bin/java -jar product-configurator.jar -e ca-eula.silent.txt -r installer.properties‚Äô

Management Module installation steps:

  1. Download WILYISMM01*.zip and Extract into the EM installation directory.
  2. Overwrite all files while extracting Management modules
  3. Execute Osgiindex.bat/osgiindex.sh (maintain 775 permissions for this file).

Note:

*use <sid>adm user instead of root account on UNIX

*Ensure you have a Diagnostics Agent installed on the host being used for the installation

 

Change password for Introscope Enterprise Manager user as per KBA2310713:

1.run SHA2Encoder script located in the <EM_Home>/tools directory.(For Windows, SHA2Encoder.bat <password>  For UNIX, SHA2encoder.sh <password>)

2.adjusting the corresponding user line, using the generated password string (the part after colon ':') as password. An example format is:
<user name="X" password="abcdef15bcd349db90dffece73e1..."/>

 

Best regards,

SAP Support

entry.title: Re: SAP GUI for Windows 8.10 Beta Program ‚Äì Call for participation
entry.content:
Hi Community,

 

"Improvements for HTML Control based on WebView2 (Edge)

Several enhancements have been implemented for the WebView2 based HTML Control:

  • Two new pages in SAP GUI options dialog can be used to configure the control
  • Data downloaded via the HTML Control is stored in a SAP GUI specific folder and the lifetime of this data can be managed (automatic deletion)
  • Trusted file types can be automatically launched after having been downloaded via the HTML Control
  • When ABAP applications open external browser windows, SSO can be managed without using the browser extension that is still required in release 8.00 

                       

             

      Thanks for your sharing, it really help us a lot.

 

 

Regards,

ZFiori.

entry.title: Re: CAP Java: No qualifying bean of type 'com.sap.cds.ser...
entry.content:
This means the service srv.invoice.archive.InvoiceArchiveConfigService and srv.invoice.form.CreateInvoiceUIService has @odata.draft.enabled annotation. The problem here is the database couldn't understand which draft is used for which. To solve this issue, specify the draft service with @Qualifier annotation and the parameter be the service's name.

@Autowired
@Qualifier("InvoiceArchiveConfigService")
private DraftService invoiceArchiveDraftService;

entry.title: Integrating SAP IBP with SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud for Demand Planning Using CI-DS
entry.content:
Overview

In a two-tier ERP model, SAP IBP (Integrated Business Planning) acts as the centralized planning tool, while SAP S/4HANA Private Cloud serves as the transactional system at the headquarters. This guide outlines how to integrate these systems using SAP Cloud Integration for Data Services (CI-DS) to enable seamless demand planning.

Step 1: Install and Configure CI-DS in the Backend System

  1. Install CI-DS Agent on the backend system (S/4HANA Private Cloud).
  2. Configure the Data Stores in CI-DS to connect to:
    • SAP S/4HANA system (source)
    • SAP IBP system (target)

Configure ‚Äú Define Default values for data Integration Between SAP IBP and SAP S4HANA Cloud Public Edition‚Äù

 Step 2: Activate Extractors in SAP S/4HANA

To extract master and transactional data, activate the relevant BW extractors.

 Key Transaction Codes:

TCode

Purpose

RSA9

Transfer Application Component Hierarchy

RSA5

Install SAP-delivered DataSources

RSA6

Display active DataSources

RSA3

Test data extraction

RSA7

Monitor delta queue

RSO2

Create generic DataSources

Execution Flow:

  1. RSA9 ‚Äì Transfer the application component hierarchy.
  2. RSA5 ‚Äì Select and install the required standard extractors.
  3. RSA6 ‚Äì Confirm activation.
  4. RSA3 ‚Äì Test the extractors.

Step 3: View iFlows in CI-DS

Once extractors are activated, corresponding iFlows become available in CI-DS.

  • These iFlows map the data from S/4HANA to IBP.
  • You can customize or schedule them for initial and delta loads.

Step 4: Configure SCPI in S/4HANA Private Cloud

In the S/4HANA system:

  1. Use transaction SCPI to configure the integration.
  2. Set up communication arrangements for:
    • SAP_COM_0008 ‚Äì Business Partner, Customer, Supplier
    • SAP_COM_0009 ‚Äì Product

Step 5: Run Initial and Delta Loads

  • Initial Load: Transfers all relevant master and transactional data.
  • Delta Load: Transfers only the changed data after the initial load.

Step 6: Integrate Master Data to IBP

  • Locations: Plants, storage locations, etc.
  • Materials: Products and product hierarchies.

 

 

Step 7: Validate and Monitor

  • Use RSA3 to test extractors.
  • Monitor CI-DS job logs for success/failure.
  • Use IBP Excel Add-In to verify data load.

entry.title: Re: aATP - Manage Substitution Locations
entry.content:
Hello @AdamHorne 

Thank you for your question.

Consider to consult KBA 3193069 & Manage Substitutions for details on how to proceed. However, the summary is, you do not need to delete and rebuild substitution rules if your scenario changes when you work with manage substitution in public cloud. Please note that each substitution rule is time-dependent. You can inactivate the rule. Thereby you stop it from being applied immediately. By maintaining an end date, the rule remains in your system for audit and reporting reference but is no longer valid after that date. You then create a new rule with the revised substitution chain. This ensures history of previous substitutions is preserved and you can track what rules were valid at different times.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Migration Guide From BOPF to RAP Business Objects
entry.content:
Introduction

With the evolution of SAP development models, Business Object Processing Framework (BOPF) is gradually being replaced by the RESTful ABAP Programming Model (RAP), which provides a more modern, cloud-ready, and Fiori-optimized approach for building business applications. To help developers transition, SAP provides a guided migration procedure that converts CDS-based BOPF Business Objects into RAP Business Objects.

This migration ensures that existing business logic, determinations, validations, and actions can be reused in the RAP model, reducing redevelopment effort while aligning applications with SAP‚Äôs strategic direction. The migration process can be executed in two modes:

  • Simulation Mode ‚Äì to check the feasibility of migration and identify potential errors or warnings.
  • Migration Mode ‚Äì to perform the actual migration of objects.

The following procedure outlines the step-by-step approach for performing this migration, including checking transactional processing (TP) and consumption views, handling transport requests, and reviewing logs to ensure a smooth transition.

Procedure

    1. In your ABAP project, navigate to your CDS based BOPF BO under BOPF Business Objects in the Project Explorer.        

       

       

    2. Open the context menu and choose RAP Business Object   Migrate....

       

    3. In the Migration to RAP Business Objects wizard, select any one of the following modes:
      ÔÇß Simulation- checks and tests for errors and warnings before performing any changes. No object is migrated productively.
      ÔÇß Migration- migrates all the related objects.
       

       

    4. Choose Next.
    5. Check the TP views of the business objects affected by the migration.

      The transactional processing (TP) views display the lists of CDS views containing the transactional processing enabled object model annotations.

    6. Choose Next.
    7. Check the consumption views of the business objects affected by migration.

      The consumption views display the list of CDS views containing the transactional processing delegated annotations.

    8. For migration, select or create a transport request for the objects.
    9. Choose Next.
    10. To start the simulation, choose Finish.
    11. For migration, read the disclaimer in the Disclaimer page and the linked migration documentation carefully as the migrated business object cannot be reverted.

      The simulation log is displayed in the BO Migration Log view. Please read the outcome carefully, as errors or warnings indicate additional manual adjustments after the migration.

    12. To continue with migration, select Continue Migration.
    13. Choose Finish.

The migration log is displayed in the BO Migration Log view. Please read the outcome carefully, as errors or warnings indicate additional manual adjustments after the migration.

Conclusion
Migrating CDS-based BOPF objects to RAP helps modernize applications while reusing existing logic and reducing redevelopment. Always start with simulation to identify issues, carefully review migration logs, and then proceed with the actual migration. This ensures a smooth transition to SAP‚Äôs strategic RAP model.
